mn119:1.1.comm: This discourse features the same meditation practices found under the “observation of the body” in the Satipaṭṭhānasutta (MN 10).

mn119:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn119:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn119:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
mn119:2.1.eng: Then after the meal, on return from almsround, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them.

mn119:2.3.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā vuttā mahānisaṃsā”ti.
mn119:2.3.eng: how the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha has said that mindfulness of the body, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.”

mn119:2.4.pli: Ayañca hidaṃ tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ antarākathā vippakatā hoti, atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena upaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mn119:2.4.eng: But their conversation was left unfinished. Then the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall. He sat on the seat spread out

mn119:2.6.pli: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
mn119:2.6.eng: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”

mn119:2.7.pli: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
mn119:2.7.eng: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about. The Buddha said:

mn119:2.9.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā vuttā mahānisaṃsā’ti.

mn119:2.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.

mn119:3.1.pli: “Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati kathaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā?
mn119:3.1.eng: “And how, mendicants, is mindfulness of the body developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?

mn119:4.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
mn119:4.1.eng: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.

mn119:4.2.eng: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.

mn119:4.3.pli: dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
mn119:4.3.eng: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’

mn119:4.4.pli: rassaṃ vā assasanto ‘rassaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṃ vā passasanto ‘rassaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
mn119:4.4.eng: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’

mn119:4.5.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’

mn119:4.6.pli: ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
mn119:4.6.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’

mn119:4.7.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
mn119:4.7.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
mn119:4.7.comm: For “memories and thoughts tied to lay life” (gehasitā sarasaṅkappā) see MN 125:23.5 and SN 54.8:5.2. | Sarasaṅkappā may be translated in two ways. Bodhi reads it as a dvanda compound (“memories and thoughts”), which takes sara as “memory” (Sanskrit smara or smṛti). The commentary, followed by Ānandajoti, explains it as dhāvanasaṅkappā (“rushing thoughts”), which assumes the sense “flow” (Sanskrit saras). Support for the dvanda interpretation comes from Sanskrit texts, where we frequently find smṛtisaṁkalpa as either two words (eg. Aitareya Upaniṣad 3.2) or a compound (Nyāyasūtra 4.2.34).

mn119:4.8.pli: Tesaṃ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṃ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
mn119:4.8.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
mn119:4.8.comm: Each practice leads directly to immersion, reminding us that mindfulness meditation is “the basis of immersion” (samādhinimitta, MN 44:12.3).

mn119:4.9.eng: That’s how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gacchanto vā ‘gacchāmī’ti pajānāti, ṭhito vā ‘ṭhitomhī’ti pajānāti, nisinno vā ‘nisinnomhī’ti pajānāti, sayāno vā ‘sayānomhī’ti pajānāti.
mn119:5.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know ‘I am walking’. When standing they know ‘I am standing’. When sitting they know ‘I am sitting’. And when lying down they know ‘I am lying down’.

mn119:5.2.pli: Yathā yathā vā panassa kāyo paṇihito hoti tathā tathā naṃ pajānāti.
mn119:5.2.eng: Whatever posture their body is in, they know it.

mn119:5.3.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
mn119:5.3.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.

mn119:5.4.pli: Tesaṃ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṃ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
mn119:5.4.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

mn119:5.5.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
mn119:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
mn119:6.1.comm: Obviously this passage is not suggesting that one enters deep meditation while going to the toilet. As per the Gradual Training, such practices form a foundation that prepares the mind for meditation.

mn119:6.2.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
mn119:6.2.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.

mn119:6.3.pli: Tesaṃ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṃ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
mn119:6.3.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

mn119:6.4.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṃ pūraṃ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
mn119:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.

mn119:7.2.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ vakkaṃ hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ papphāsaṃ antaṃ antaguṇaṃ udariyaṃ karīsaṃ pittaṃ semhaṃ pubbo lohitaṃ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.
mn119:7.2.eng: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’

mn119:7.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ubhatomukhā putoḷi pūrā nānāvihitassa dhaññassa, seyyathidaṃ—
mn119:7.3.eng: It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as

mn119:7.4.pli: sālīnaṃ vīhīnaṃ muggānaṃ māsānaṃ tilānaṃ taṇḍulānaṃ,
mn119:7.4.eng: fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice.

mn119:7.5.eng: And a person with clear eyes were to open it and examine the contents:

mn119:7.6.pli: ‘ime sālī ime vīhī ime muggā ime māsā ime tilā ime taṇḍulā’ti;
mn119:7.6.eng: ‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’

mn119:7.7.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṃ pūraṃ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
mn119:7.7.eng: In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth. …
mn119:7.7.comm: Such meditations, as also the contemplation on death that follow, lead to immersion by ridding the mind of desire. While the subject of meditation is perceived as unpleasant, when the mind is free of desire it gives rise to a pleasure imbued with lightness and freedom, and it is that pleasure that leads to immersion.

mn119:7.8.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ vakkaṃ hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ papphāsaṃ antaṃ antaguṇaṃ udariyaṃ karīsaṃ pittaṃ semhaṃ pubbo lohitaṃ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.

mn119:7.9.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
mn119:7.9.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.

mn119:7.10.pli: Tesaṃ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṃ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
mn119:7.10.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

mn119:7.11.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ yathāṭhitaṃ yathāpaṇihitaṃ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
mn119:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:

mn119:8.2.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
mn119:8.2.eng: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’

mn119:8.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṃ vadhitvā catumahāpathe bilaso vibhajitvā nisinno assa;
mn119:8.3.eng: It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into chops.

mn119:8.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ yathāṭhitaṃ yathāpaṇihitaṃ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
mn119:8.4.eng: In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:

mn119:8.5.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
mn119:8.5.eng: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’

mn119:8.6.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
mn119:8.6.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.

mn119:8.7.pli: Tesaṃ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṃ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
mn119:8.7.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

mn119:8.8.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ ekāhamataṃ vā dvīhamataṃ vā tīhamataṃ vā uddhumātakaṃ vinīlakaṃ vipubbakajātaṃ.
mn119:9.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.

mn119:9.2.eng: They’d compare it with their own body:

mn119:9.3.eng: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

mn119:9.4.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
mn119:9.4.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.

mn119:9.5.pli: Tesaṃ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṃ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
mn119:9.5.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

mn119:9.6.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ kākehi vā khajjamānaṃ kulalehi vā khajjamānaṃ gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṃ kaṅkehi vā khajjamānaṃ sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṃ byagghehi vā khajjamānaṃ dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṃ siṅgālehi vā khajjamānaṃ vividhehi vā pāṇakajātehi khajjamānaṃ.
mn119:10.1.eng: Or suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, hounds, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures.

mn119:10.2.eng: They’d compare it with their own body:

mn119:10.3.eng: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

mn119:10.5.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:11-14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ samaṃsalohitaṃ nhārusambandhaṃ …pe…
mn119:11-14.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

mn119:11-14.2.eng: A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews …

mn119:11-14.3.eng: A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

mn119:11-14.4.pli: aṭṭhikāni apagatasambandhāni disāvidisāvikkhittāni aññena hatthaṭṭhikaṃ aññena pādaṭṭhikaṃ aññena gopphakaṭṭhikaṃ aññena jaṅghaṭṭhikaṃ aññena ūruṭṭhikaṃ aññena kaṭiṭṭhikaṃ aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṃ aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṃ aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṃ aññena gīvaṭṭhikaṃ aññena hanukaṭṭhikaṃ aññena dantaṭṭhikaṃ aññena sīsakaṭāhaṃ.
mn119:11-14.4.eng: Bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here an ankle bone, there a shin-bone, here a thigh-bone, there a hip-bone, here a rib-bone, there a back-bone, here an arm-bone, there a neck-bone, here a jaw-bone, there a tooth, here the skull. …

mn119:15-17.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ—

mn119:15-17.2.eng: White bones, the color of shells …

mn119:15-17.3.eng: Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile …

mn119:15-17.4.eng: Bones rotted and crumbled to powder.

mn119:15-17.5.eng: They’d compare it with their own body:

mn119:15-17.6.eng: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

mn119:15-17.7.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to lay life are given up.

mn119:15-17.8.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

mn119:15-17.9.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:18.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn119:18.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn119:18.1.comm: In the Satipaṭṭhānasutta, the practice of absorption is implicit in the contemplation of feelings (as spiritual pleasure), mind (as immersed mind, etc.), and principles (as the awakening factor of immersion), while the four absorptions are mentioned explicitly in the expanded version (DN 22:21.32). Here they take an even more central role.

mn119:18.2.pli: So imameva kāyaṃ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mn119:18.2.eng: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
mn119:18.2.comm: As a meditator proceeds, their subjective experience of the “body” evolves from tactile sense impressions (phoṭṭhabba), to the interior mental experience of bliss and light (manomayakāya), to the direct personal realization of highest truth (MN 70:23.2: kāyena ceva paramasaccaṁ sacchikaroti).

mn119:18.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho nhāpako vā nhāpakantevāsī vā kaṃsathāle nhānīyacuṇṇāni ākiritvā udakena paripphosakaṃ paripphosakaṃ sanneyya, sāyaṃ nhānīyapiṇḍi snehānugatā snehaparetā santarabāhirā phuṭā snehena na ca pagghariṇī;
mn119:18.3.eng: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
mn119:18.3.comm: The kneading is the “placing the mind and keeping it connected”, the water is bliss, while the lack of leaking speaks to the contained interiority of the experience.

mn119:18.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mn119:18.4.eng: In the same way, they drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.

mn119:18.5.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to lay life are given up.

mn119:18.6.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

mn119:18.7.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:19.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn119:19.1.eng: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn119:19.2.pli: So imameva kāyaṃ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mn119:19.2.eng: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.

mn119:19.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakarahado gambhīro ubbhidodako. Tassa nevassa puratthimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ na pacchimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ na uttarāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ na dakkhiṇāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ; devo ca na kālena kālaṃ sammā dhāraṃ anuppaveccheyya; atha kho tamhāva udakarahadā sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvā tameva udakarahadaṃ sītena vārinā abhisandeyya parisandeyya paripūreyya paripphareyya, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato udakarahadassa sītena vārinā apphuṭaṃ assa;
mn119:19.3.eng: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and the heavens would not properly bestow showers from time to time. But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
mn119:19.3.comm: The simile emphasizes the water as bliss, while the lack of inflow expresses containment and unification. The water welling up is the rapture, which is the uplifting emotional response to the experience of bliss. These similes are also at DN 2:78.1, DN 10:2.16.1, MN39:16.1, MN 77:26.3, and AN 5.28:3.4.

mn119:19.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mn119:19.4.eng: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.

mn119:19.6.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:20.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn119:20.1.eng: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn119:20.2.pli: So imameva kāyaṃ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mn119:20.2.eng: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.

mn119:20.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uppaliniyaṃ vā paduminiyaṃ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni paripūrāni paripphuṭāni, nāssa kiñci sabbāvataṃ uppalānaṃ vā padumānaṃ vā puṇḍarīkānaṃ vā sītena vārinā apphuṭaṃ assa;
mn119:20.3.eng: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
mn119:20.3.comm: The meditator is utterly immersed in stillness and bliss.

mn119:20.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mn119:20.4.eng: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.

mn119:20.6.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:21.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn119:21.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn119:21.2.pli: So imameva kāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mn119:21.2.eng: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not filled with pure bright mind.

mn119:21.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṃ assa;
mn119:21.3.eng: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
mn119:21.3.comm: The white cloth is the purity and brightness of equanimity. The commentary explains this as a person who has just got out of a bath and sits perfectly dry and content.

mn119:21.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mn119:21.4.eng: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not filled with pure bright mind.

mn119:21.5.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
mn119:21.5.eng: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.

mn119:21.6.pli: Tesaṃ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṃ santiṭṭhati, sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
mn119:21.6.eng: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.

mn119:21.7.eng: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.

mn119:22.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, antogadhāvāssa kusalā dhammā ye keci vijjābhāgiyā.
mn119:22.1.eng: Anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.
mn119:22.1.comm: By this, the Buddha is asserting that mindfulness of the body is not just the first of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, but encompasses all of them. The body is the arena within which feelings, mind, and principles become apparent. (Also at AN 1.575.) | The things that “play a part in realization” are enumerated as two at AN 2.31: serenity and discernment. Another group of six at SN 55.3:4.1 and AN 6.35 focus on the discernment side (observing impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation).

mn119:22.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci mahāsamuddo cetasā phuṭo, antogadhāvāssa kunnadiyo yā kāci samuddaṅgamā;
mn119:22.2.eng: Anyone who brings into their mind the great ocean includes all of the streams that run down into it.
mn119:22.2.comm: A simile of the rivers becoming united in the ocean is also found at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.11, Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 3.2.8, and Praśna Upaniṣad 6.5.

mn119:22.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, antogadhāvāssa kusalā dhammā ye keci vijjābhāgiyā.
mn119:22.3.eng: In the same way, anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.

mn119:23.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati abhāvitā abahulīkatā, labhati tassa māro otāraṃ, labhati tassa māro ārammaṇaṃ.
mn119:23.1.eng: When a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets an opportunity.

mn119:23.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso garukaṃ silāguḷaṃ allamattikāpuñje pakkhipeyya.
mn119:23.2.eng: Suppose a person were to throw a heavy stone ball at a mound of wet clay.

mn119:23.4.pli: api nu taṃ garukaṃ silāguḷaṃ allamattikāpuñje labhetha otāran”ti?
mn119:23.4.eng: Would that heavy stone ball find an entry into that mound of wet clay?”

mn119:23.6.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati abhāvitā abahulīkatā, labhati tassa māro otāraṃ, labhati tassa māro ārammaṇaṃ.
mn119:23.6.eng: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets an opportunity.

mn119:24.1.eng: Suppose there was a dried up, withered log.

mn119:24.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking

mn119:24.3.eng: to light a fire and produce heat.

mn119:24.5.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ sukkhaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ koḷāpaṃ uttarāraṇiṃ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
mn119:24.5.eng: By drilling the stick against that dried up, withered log, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

mn119:24.7.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati abhāvitā abahulīkatā, labhati tassa māro otāraṃ, labhati tassa māro ārammaṇaṃ.
mn119:24.7.eng: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets an opportunity.

mn119:25.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakamaṇiko ritto tuccho ādhāre ṭhapito;
mn119:25.1.eng: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, empty and hollow.

mn119:25.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a load of water.

mn119:25.4.pli: api nu so puriso labhetha udakassa nikkhepanan”ti?
mn119:25.4.eng: Could that person pour water into the jar?”

mn119:25.6.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati abhāvitā abahulīkatā, labhati tassa māro otāraṃ, labhati tassa māro ārammaṇaṃ.
mn119:25.6.eng: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets an opportunity.

mn119:26.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, na tassa labhati māro otāraṃ, na tassa labhati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
mn119:26.1.eng: When a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get an opportunity.

mn119:26.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso lahukaṃ suttaguḷaṃ sabbasāramaye aggaḷaphalake pakkhipeyya.
mn119:26.2.eng: Suppose a person were to throw a light ball of string at a door-panel made entirely of hardwood.
mn119:26.2.comm: Compare the simile at Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.2.7 and Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.3.7, where the titans (or forces of evil) meet their end in the breath, just like a clod of earth thrown against solid rock.

mn119:26.4.pli: api nu so puriso taṃ lahukaṃ suttaguḷaṃ sabbasāramaye aggaḷaphalake labhetha otāran”ti?
mn119:26.4.eng: Would that light ball of string find an entry into that door-panel made entirely of hardwood?”

mn119:26.6.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, na tassa labhati māro otāraṃ, na tassa labhati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
mn119:26.6.eng: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get an opportunity.

mn119:27.1.eng: Suppose there was a green, sappy log.

mn119:27.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking

mn119:27.3.eng: to light a fire and produce heat.

mn119:27.5.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ allaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ sasnehaṃ uttarāraṇiṃ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
mn119:27.5.eng: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

mn119:27.7.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, na tassa labhati māro otāraṃ, na tassa labhati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
mn119:27.7.eng: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get an opportunity.

mn119:28.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakamaṇiko pūro udakassa samatittiko kākapeyyo ādhāre ṭhapito;
mn119:28.1.eng: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
mn119:28.1.comm: These similes recall the absorption similes above.

mn119:28.2.eng: Then a person comes along with a load of water.

mn119:28.4.pli: api nu so puriso labhetha udakassa nikkhepanan”ti?
mn119:28.4.eng: Could that person pour water into the jar?”

mn119:28.6.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, na tassa labhati māro otāraṃ, na tassa labhati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
mn119:28.6.eng: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra cannot find a vulnerability and doesn’t get an opportunity.

mn119:29.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, so yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
mn119:29.1.eng: When a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.

mn119:29.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakamaṇiko pūro udakassa samatittiko kākapeyyo ādhāre ṭhapito.
mn119:29.2.eng: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.

mn119:29.3.pli: Tamenaṃ balavā puriso yato yato āviñcheyya, āgaccheyya udakan”ti?
mn119:29.3.eng: If a strong man was to pour it on any side, would water pour out?”

mn119:29.5.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā so, yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
mn119:29.5.eng: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.
mn119:29.5.comm: The phrase sati sati āyatane is tricky. Syntactically, it is a locative absolute construction, which Bodhi treats as conditional: “there being a suitable basis”. However this does not readily account for the repeated sati, which he takes as the locative present participle from the verb atthi (“being”). Ānandajoti, by contrast, takes the first sati as “being” and the second as “mindfulness”, and treats the absolute construction as temporal: “while there is a basis for mindfulness”. Further, both accept the commentary’s gloss of āyatana as kāraṇa (“reason, basis”), although this sense of āyatana is rare in the suttas (but see SN 12.25:14.3 = AN 4.171:5.3). These readings of the absolute construction give it a limiting sense; the benefits apply only insofar as there is a “suitable basis” or a “basis for mindfulness”. But the expression is used by the Buddha of himself (AN 5.68:1.9), so it seems odd that it would be limiting. Indeed, the tenor of the whole sentence is not limiting but expansive, as emphasized by the repeated reduplications: yassa yassa … tatra tatreva … sati sati, which have a distributive sense. I therefore take sati as “being” in both cases; the reduplication of sati as aligned with the preceding pronouns, emphasizing universality; the locative absolute as causal; and āyatana in its normal sense of “scope, range”.

mn119:30.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, same bhūmibhāge caturassā pokkharaṇī assa āḷibandhā pūrā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā.
mn119:30.1.eng: Suppose there was a square, walled lotus pond on level ground, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.

mn119:30.2.pli: Tamenaṃ balavā puriso yato yato āḷiṃ muñceyya āgaccheyya udakan”ti?
mn119:30.2.eng: If a strong man was to open the wall on any side, would water pour out?”

mn119:30.4.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, so yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
mn119:30.4.eng: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.

mn119:31.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, subhūmiyaṃ catumahāpathe ājaññaratho yutto assa ṭhito odhastapatodo;
mn119:31.1.eng: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.

mn119:31.2.pli: tamenaṃ dakkho yoggācariyo assadammasārathi abhiruhitvā vāmena hatthena rasmiyo gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena patodaṃ gahetvā yenicchakaṃ yadicchakaṃ sāreyyāpi paccāsāreyyāpi;
mn119:31.2.eng: A deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.

mn119:31.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā, so yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
mn119:31.3.eng: In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.

mn119:32.1.pli: Kāyagatāya, bhikkhave, satiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya dasānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
mn119:32.1.eng: You can expect ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.

mn119:33.1.pli: Aratiratisaho hoti, na ca taṃ arati sahati, uppannaṃ aratiṃ abhibhuyya viharati.
mn119:33.1.eng: They prevail over desire and discontent, and live having mastered desire and discontent whenever they arose.

mn119:34.1.pli: Bhayabheravasaho hoti, na ca taṃ bhayabheravaṃ sahati, uppannaṃ bhayabheravaṃ abhibhuyya viharati.
mn119:34.1.eng: They prevail over fear and dread, and live having mastered fear and dread whenever they arose.

mn119:35.1.pli: Khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṃ duruttānaṃ durāgatānaṃ vacanapathānaṃ, uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ adhivāsakajātiko hoti.
mn119:35.1.eng: They endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

mn119:36.1.pli: Catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
mn119:36.1.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

mn119:37.1.pli: So anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccānubhoti. Ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti, āvibhāvaṃ …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti.
mn119:37.1.eng: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … They control the body as far as the realm of divinity.

mn119:38.1.pli: Dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike ca …pe….
mn119:38.1.eng: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far. …

mn119:39.1.pli: Parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti.
mn119:39.1.eng: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind. …

mn119:40.1.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
mn119:40.1.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

mn119:41.1.pli: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
mn119:41.1.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

mn119:42.1.pli: Āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
mn119:42.1.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

mn119:43.1.pli: Kāyagatāya, bhikkhave, satiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ime dasānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
mn119:43.1.eng: You can expect these ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.”

mn119:43.2.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn119:43.3.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn119:43.3.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
